# 2024 New York Democratic presidential primary

| image1 = File:Joe Biden presidential portrait (cropped).jpg
| image_size = 160x160px
| candidate1 = Joe Biden
| color1 = 224192
| home_state1 = Delaware
| popular_vote1 = 288,138
| percentage1 = 80.7%
| delegate_count1 = 268
| image2             = File:NOTA Option Logo 3x4.svg
| candidate2         = Blank ballots
| color2             = 000000
| home_state2        = –
| delegate_count2    = 0

| percentage2        = 11.5%
}}
The 2024 New York Democratic presidential primary was held on April 2, 2024, as part of the Democratic Party primaries for the 2024 presidential election. 306 delegates to the Democratic National Convention will be allocated to presidential candidates.
President Biden won every county, but blank ballots, fueled by protest votes due to the Gaza war, received more than 11% of the vote statewide, and more than 14% of the vote in New York City.
Candidates
Incumbent President Joe Biden announced his bid for a second term on April 25, 2023. He faced a primary challenge from author, progressive activist, and 2020 presidential candidate Marianne Williamson, and former Congressman Dean Phillips. All three candidates filed to appear on the ballot by the January 19, 2024, filing deadline.
New York also officially tallies and reports the number of voters who leave their ballots blank. New York does not give voters the option of voting "uncommitted" the way that some other states do, but protest votes can be registered by submitting a blank ballot.
Endorsements
Forbes 3050 Summit |url=https://www.forbes.com/video/6322204085112/hillary-clinton-discusses-leadership-2024-and-opportunities-for-women--forbes-3050-summit/ |access-date=May 3, 2023 |website=Forbes |language=en}}
* James Comey, Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation (2013–2017), United States Deputy Attorney General (2003–2005), United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York (2002–2003) (Independent)
US Senators
* Kirsten Gillibrand, New York (2009–present), U.S. Representative from NY-20 (2007–2009)
* Chuck Schumer, New York (1999–present), Senate Majority Leader (2021–present), Senate Minority Leader (2017–2021), U.S. Representative from NY-09 (1993–1999), NY-10 (1983–1993) and NY-16 (1981–1983)
US Representatives
* Jamaal Bowman, NY-16 (2021–present)
* Grace Meng, NY-06 (2013–present)
* Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, NY-14 (2019–present)
* Pat Ryan, NY-18 (2023–present), NY-19 (2022–2023)
* Thomas Downey, NY-02 (1975–1993)
* Carolyn Maloney, NY-12 (2013–2023) and NY-14 (1993–2013)
* Tom Suozzi, NY-03 (2017–2023, 2024–present), candidate for Governor of New York in 2022
State officials
* Kathy Hochul, Governor of New York (2021–present); Lieutenant Governor of New York (2015–2021); U.S. Representative for NY-26 (2011–2013)
* Andrew Cuomo, Governor of New York (2011–2021); Attorney General of New York (2007–2011); United States Secretary of Housing and Urban Development (1997–2001)
Mayors
* Eric Adams, 110th mayor of New York City, New York (2022–present)
Individuals
* Jack Schlossberg, grandson of John F. Kennedy.
Organizations
* Democratic Party of New York|title=Joe Biden}}
}}
*Working Families Party
State senators
*Jabari Brisport, state senator from the 18th district (2021–present)
State assemblymembers
*Zohran Mamdani, state assemblymember from the 36th district (2021–present)
*Marcela Mitaynes, state assemblymember from the 51st district (2021–present)
*Phara Souffrant Forrest, state assemblymember from the 57th district (2021–present)
Local officials
*Tiffany Cabán, New York City Councilmember from the 22nd district (2022–present), former candidate for Queens County District Attorney in 2019
*Shahana Hanif, New York City Councilmember from the 39th district (2022–present)
*Sandy Nurse, New York City Councilmember from the 37th district (2022–present)
*Alexa Avilés, New York City Councilmember from the 38th district (2022–present)
}}
Results
Delegates elected by district
Voters elect state-level (at-large) delegates via presidential preference vote and directly elect congressional district-level delegates. Each campaign normally submits a slate to the New York State Board of Elections. However, only the Biden campaign submitted a slate by the nomination deadline. As a result, the following congressional district-level delegates will be elected by default:
